descriptions.content:
Adjectives can be thought of as having “short” and “long” forms. The short form of an adjective is an adjective’s monosyllabic root; this short form hardly ever appears alone.

For example, the short form of གསར་པ་ “new” would be གསར་; the short form of མངར་མོ་ “sweet” would be མངར་; the short form of མང་པོ་ “many” would be མང་, and so forth. An important exception to this rule is the adjective ཆེན་པོ་ “big,” of which the short form is ཆེ་ and not ཆེན་.

All adjectival suffixes are attached to the short form of the adjective. For example, the adjective ཆུང་ཆུང་ “small” can be reduced to its short form ཆུང་; adjectival suffixes can then be attached to this single syllable to produce:

  • ཆུང་བ་ “Smaller”
  • ཆུང་དྲགས་ “Too small”
  • ཆུང་ལོས་ “How small?”
  • ཆུང་ཤོས་ “The smallest”
  • ཆུང་ཙམ་ “A bit small”
  • ཆུང་བ་ལ་ “How small!”
